name: Felix Heide
content: Felix Heide Felix Heide Professor Princeton University Princeton Computational Imaging Lab fheide@cs.princeton.edu Latest News: Nov 2025 Spin-out Cephia AI from my lab raises $4M in seed funding ! Oct 2025 I won the Princeton Dean for Research Distinguished Innovation Award ! Aug 2025 New paper on inverse neural rendering for computer vision in Nature Machine Intelligence, and four papers in this year's SIGGRAPH 2025 and SIGGRAPH Asia 2025 ! June 2025 New papers on optical computing in Science Advances and Nature Communication ! March 2025 Research on AI at the speed of light covered in "A new way of seeing, a new way of computing" and "Identifing objects at the speed of light"! July 2024 We will present two papers at this year's SIGGRAPH 2024 and another two papers at SIGGRAPH Asia 2024 ! April 2024 My group will present 9 fun papers at CVPR 2024. Aug 2023 I won the Significant New Researcher Award at SIGGRAPH 2023! May 2023 Thrilled to announce that Algolux has been acquired! Together with Torc's robotic stack and the deep OEM integration with Daimler Truck AG we will bring Algolux's perception in autonomous trucks on the road at scale ! Feb 2023 I was named a 2023 Sloan Research Fellow. Jan 2023 I got named a Packard Fellow from the Packard Foundation Fellowships for Science and Engineering. Biography I'm a professor of Computer Science at Princeton, where I lead the Princeton Computational Imaging Lab, and I am the Head of AI at Torc Robotics which builds full autonomy stacks for self-driving trucks. I previously founded the startup Algolux which was acquired by Torc and Daimler Trucks. My group at Princeton explores imaging and computer vision approaches that allow computers to see and understand what seems invisible today — enabling super-human capabilities for the cameras in our vehicles, personal devices, microscopes, telescopes, and the instrumentation we use for fundamental research in physics. This includes today's capture and vision challenges, including harsh environmental conditions, e.g., imaging under ultra-low or high illumination or computer vision through dense fog, rain, and snow, imaging at ultra-fast or slow time scales, freezing light in motion, imaging at extreme scene scales, from super-resolution microscopy to kilometer-scale depth sensing, and imaging via proxies using nearby object surfaces as sensors instead. Researching vision systems end-to-end, my work lies at the intersection of optics, machine learning, optimization, computer graphics, and computer vision. I received my Ph.D. from the University of British Columbia, and I was a postdoc at Stanford University. My doctoral dissertation won the Alain Fournier Ph.D. Dissertation Award and the SIGGRAPH outstanding doctoral dissertation award. I was recently named SIGGRAPH Significant New Researcher, Sloan Research Fellow and Packard Fellow.
